hints.content:
There are $\blueD{9}$ groups.

They are $\greenD{27}$ total students.

[[☃ image 1]]

What is the $\purpleC{\text{size of the groups}}$?

options.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal lengths. The first tape is labeled 27 and the second tape has 9 equal parts each labeled with a question mark. A curved bracket across the bottom and the width of the second tape is labeled with the words 9 equal groups. !

hints.content:
We can write this as a multiplication problem. 

$\blueD{\text{ number of groups}}\times\purpleC{\text{size of the group}}= \greenD{\text{ total}}$

So, $\blueD{9}\times\purpleC{\text{?}} = \greenD{27}$

We can also write this as a division problem. 

$\greenD{\text{total}}\div\blueD{\text{ number of groups}}=\purpleC{\text{ size of the groups}}$

So, $\greenD{27}\div \blueD{9}=\purpleC{\text{?}}$

The equations that would help us find out how many students are in each group are:  

 - $\blueD{9}\times\purpleC{\text{?}} = \greenD{27}$
 - $\greenD{27}\div \blueD{9}=\purpleC{\text{?}}$

question.content:
There are $27$ students in art class.  For the sculpture project, the students are split into $9$ groups.  Each group has the same number of students.

**Which equations would help us find out how many students are in each group?**

[[☃ radio 1]]
